text:
Couple of months ago I made a presentation in my university called "Towards efficient development tools".
Now it is finally published on YouTube. I would love to hear your feedback.

In presentation I tried to show the possibility and need for better tools. I did a short overview of existing FoC projects, talked a bit about project I am working on: a generic tree editor (structure editor) that doesn't tied up to any PL. I also talked about idea of designing PL by balancing Order and Chaos, ideas that I got from Jordan Peterson.

I believe that breakaway from text-based editing towards structure-based is an inevitable event for future of programming.
I also have some other ideas about programming languages that I would like to build on top of this tree editing platform, but it is not covered in presentation.

I decided to make an academic career, that's why I've enrolled to university.
This presentation is small step that I've attempted towards that direction.

<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t8UH3DjvxDE>

text:
Looks great, though I was wondering if the slides were complete.

For academic rigor it's worth mentioning the drawback of modifying just the programming environment and not the language: since you're retrofitting the language with concerns it wasn't designed for, it's harder to do science. A negative result may not tell you much, just that your particular approach doesn't work.

text: Very interseting presentation. I like (and share) the idea of designing an programming environment that provides a base structure for code and API for visual DSLs!

elements.text: Very interseting presentation. I like (and share) the idea of designing an programming environment that provides a base structure for code and API for visual DSLs!

text:
Thank you!

I just realized that many good features are much simplier with structured code, yet structured editing is very complicated. I thought that simple and generic editor for trees could open up opportunities for further experimentation.

elements.text:
Thank you!

I just realized that many good features are much simplier with structured code, yet structured editing is very complicated. I thought that simple and generic editor for trees could open up opportunities for further experimentation.

text: What do you use to develop your environment? Is it a desktop application? With which language(s)? A web app? Other?

elements.text: What do you use to develop your environment? Is it a desktop application? With which language(s)? A web app? Other?

text: It is a web app, just a React application in JavaScript. I want to attach a git repository as a storage for backend since git is just a DAG storage.

elements.text: It is a web app, just a React application in JavaScript. I want to attach a git repository as a storage for backend since git is just a DAG storage.

text: For now there is very little backend, but likely I gonna do it in Go, because it is relatively popular and more or less convenient for me.

elements.text: For now there is very little backend, but likely I gonna do it in Go, because it is relatively popular and more or less convenient for me.

text: I am trying to make process of editing as similar to text as possible, so it would be easier to adopt.

elements.text: I am trying to make process of editing as similar to text as possible, so it would be easier to adopt.

text: Actually, I am not sure how I can do solid scientific work here yet. Very hard to measure improvement.

elements.text: Actually, I am not sure how I can do solid scientific work here yet. Very hard to measure improvement.

text: For similar needs I plan to try Dark as a backend. Not sure it is the most appropriate, but the "no infra/no deploy" feature is nice, and I want to give Dark a try.

elements.text: For similar needs I plan to try Dark as a backend. Not sure it is the most appropriate, but the "no infra/no deploy" feature is nice, and I want to give Dark a try.

text: I'm thinking about starting (or joining) a startup in 2020. Would love it if people would vote on the 4 ideas I'm considering: <https://forms.gle/3BovuuEMCLJgrasw9>

attachments.title: 2020 Business Ideas
attachments.text: I've got a number of projects I enjoy working on and want to decide which, if any, to focus on and turn into a startup. Thanks for your feedback! -Breck

text: Love the slides <@UCKRZS3DZ>. I really like this visual:

elements.text: Love the slides
. I really like this visual:

text: I've been researching Tree languages for a while. I am not sure if future AIs will store knowledge/information as Trees, but it certainly seems that trees are the way humans make complexity understandable.

elements.text: I've been researching Tree languages for a while. I am not sure if future AIs will store knowledge/information as Trees, but it certainly seems that trees are the way humans make complexity understandable.

text: I've been working on a family of spatial languages that are a departure from traditional languages. The Tree is the primary structure (and things like lists, sets, maps, functions are specific types of trees; even primitives are fundamentally composed of lower level trees).

elements.text: I've been working on a family of spatial languages that are a departure from traditional languages. The Tree is the primary structure (and things like lists, sets, maps, functions are specific types of trees; even primitives are fundamentally composed of lower level trees).

text: Program editors are kind of a hybrid of traditional text editor with spreadsheets. You can work with a program like a traditional text sequence or edit it on a spreadsheet like grid. Layout is the only syntax—no quotes or brackets or parens. Lots of different parsing approaches can be used.

elements.text: Program editors are kind of a hybrid of traditional text editor with spreadsheets. You can work with a program like a traditional text sequence or edit it on a spreadsheet like grid. Layout is the only syntax—no quotes or brackets or parens. Lots of different parsing approaches can be used.

text: Anyway, if you ever wanted to discuss trees and new editor approaches feel free to ping me

elements.text: Anyway, if you ever wanted to discuss trees and new editor approaches feel free to ping me

text: Science doesn't have to be quantitative. When a domain has few variables and concrete metrics, science is quantitative. When it has lots of variables and metrics are unclear, you can still follow the spirit of Science. The key is to ask yourself: how would I know this is a bad idea? What does it take to _falsify_ it to my own satisfaction, so that I can switch gears and go work on something else with a clear conscience?

elements.text: Science doesn't have to be quantitative. When a domain has few variables and concrete metrics, science is quantitative. When it has lots of variables and metrics are unclear, you can still follow the spirit of Science. The key is to ask yourself: how would I know this is a bad idea? What does it take to
falsify
it to my own satisfaction, so that I can switch gears and go work on something else with a clear conscience?

text: Any of these could be good ideas, but I think it's tough to say much without knowing what problems they are solving and for whom(and why a solution would make them really excited!).

elements.text: Any of these could be good ideas, but I think it's tough to say much without knowing what problems they are solving and for whom(and why a solution would make them really excited!).

text: In my experience, binding trees model most programming languages well.  That is keep track of tree structure and how lexical variables are bound so that if you move a block of code out of its scope, you see what parameters need to be passed in.

elements.text: In my experience, binding trees model most programming languages well.  That is keep track of tree structure and how lexical variables are bound so that if you move a block of code out of its scope, you see what parameters need to be passed in.

text:
<@UMVFWPZ36> Thank you! I like good visual design and try to make things pleasant for eyes.

I've seen your Tree Notation. I find the idea beautiful, although it is not directly connected to what I work on.

>  Anyway, if you ever wanted to discuss trees and new editor approaches feel free to ping me
Sure! Right now I am a bit busy, but would love to have a one-on-one talk with you a week later or so.
